results.title: People of the cities
results.creator_credit: Arch Nicholson, Tom Manefield, John Abbott and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Russians”.
An inside look at how the Russians live, showing actual families in their homes, at work and their entertainment. This film deals with city life, in places such as Moscow and Odessa. Narrator, Nick Tate.

results.title: The Russians
results.creator_credit: Arch Nicholson, Tom Manefield, John Abbott and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Russians”.
A three part series examining life in the Soviet Union. This episode studies Kierov, Kuban, Belarussia and Siberia. Narrated by Nick Tate, cinematography by Dean Semler.

results.title: Hadrian's Wall: the edge of empire
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Romans in Britain”.
The third program in the “Roman’s in Britain” series which discusses the history of one of the most famous landmarks of Roman Britain, Hadrian’s Wall. Through interviews with historians, archaeologists and museum curators and a discussion of artifacts and construction patterns present at the site, this episode explores the various theories about who built the wall, its purpose for the Roman Empire, and the impact it had on early Britain. A commentary on the gradual downfall of the Romans in Britain and their remaining legacy in a variety of forms in the country concludes the program.

results.title: Coming of age
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Romans in Britain”.
The second program in the Roman’s in Britain series which discusses the progression of the Roman rule over Britain over 4 centuries. It focuses on the history of the development of cities in Britain under the Roman Empire and their development of the notion of the country being a unified entity, a province governed from the centre rather than being separately managed tribal lands. This was symbolised most strikingly by the Roman’s establishment of the port town of London as a capital city and the legacy of 400 years worth of road construction across the country for ease of trade and travel between districts. The program also looks at the influence of the Roman empire over food preparation, the establishment of bath houses, architectural traditions, dynamics of the marketplace and the establishment of industrial complexes in early Britain. In the process the merging of the Celtic cultural landscape with that of Rome is examined, with discussion of the acknowledgement of the different cultures within the constructions of the Roman Empire in Britain as each country became a visible part of the other.

results.title: Roman fact, Roman fable
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Romans in Britain”.
The first installment of the Roman’s in Britain Series discusses the history of Britain in relation to the Roman invasion and occupation of its shores over a number of centuries. The program explores the tribal groups that previously occupied the area and the systematic take over that the Romans succeeded in achieving in AD43 and the subsequent impact this had on the cultural and societal life of the previous inhabitants. Through thorough narration, interviews with historians and archaeologists, reenactments, reconstructions of archaeological findings and excerpts from film and television depictions of this historical period the various myths, facts and speculations about this time in history are explored and analysed with a view to creating an accurate perspective on the classical past in Britain and the Roman impact on the country that is still visible today.

group_siblings.title: Hadrian's Wall: the edge of empire

results.title: The Romans in Britain
results.brief_description: Three part series covering the centuries beginning and ending the Roman occupation of early Britain. The series traces the social, political and cultural impact of the Roman Empire on early Britain and the future of the country and investigates various historical landmarks and events that signal the significance of the Roman presence and influence. Other subjects discussed include culinary, architectural, religious and community planning traditions of Roman Britain, all illustrated through interviews with historians, archaeologists and re-enactment troups as well as investigation of artifacts and characteristics and representations of this period in contemporary England. “Roman’s in Britain” is a comprehensive investigation of the history of Rome and of Britain, and their mutually influential position in classical history.

results.title: Vienna: stripping the facade
results.creator_credit: David M. Thompson, Robert Phillip, Open University and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Rise of Modernism in Music 1890-1935”.
Traces the development of Viennese modernism during the period before World War 1, concentrating on the buildings of Otto Wagner and Adolf Loos, the paintings of Klimt, Kokoschka, Schiele, and Gerstl, and the music and paintings of Schoenberg. It also includes a brief extract from Kokoschka’s play, “Murderer, Hope of Women.”
results.creator_credit_for_label: David M. Thompson, Robert Phillip, Open University and BBC-TV

results.title: Are my ears on wrong?
results.creator_credit: Robert Phillip, David M. Thompson and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Rise of Modernism in Music 1890-1935”.
A profile of Charles Ives, one of America’s most important twentieth century composers, including interviews with composers Aaron Copland and Elliot Carter, performances by the Chilingirian String Quartet and BBC Symphony Orchestra, dramatised sequences of Ives childhood, an extract from Ives’ “Concord Sonata” played by John Kirkpatrick and filmed in Ives own studio.
